sentences: Ruth Jean Baskerville Bowen (1924–2009) was the first black female talent agent and the president of Queen Booking Corporation, the largest Black-owned entertainment and talent agency in the world.
Ruth Jean Baskerville was born to Marion Baskerville and Claude Carlton on September 13, 1924, in Danville, Virginia.
She studied at New York University for two years before getting married.
After marrying in 1944, Ruth Bowen initially gained hands-on experience in the entertainment industry by handling her husband Billy Bowen's business affairs.
A singer, he was one of the original members of The Ink Spots, and toured with them around the country in the 1940s and 1950s.

According to one source, while on tour with her husband and the Ink Spots in Pittsburgh, Bowen spotted Washington's tour bus and her husband introduced them.[1] Another story is that "Major Robinson, a nationally syndicated columnist, introduced Bowen to Dinah Washington in 1945."
Together with Washington, she started a booking agency, Queen Artists, in 1959.
By 1964, after the death of Washington, Bowen renamed her company as the Queen Booking Corporation.
Ruth Bowen married William "Billy" Bowen, one of the original members of The Ink Spots, in 1944.
They were married until his death in 1982.
Bowen died at the age of 84 on April 21, 2009 in New York City after battling brain cancer.
